buddhist.text: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts. If a man speaks or acts with an evil thought, pain follows him, as the wheel follows the foot of the ox that draws the carriage.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Our very being is shaped by our thoughts. Evil thoughts invariably lead to suffering. This pain follows like a cart's wheel follows the ox's hoof. It highlights the direct, inescapable consequence of negative thinking.

buddhist.text: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: it is founded on our thoughts, it is made up of our thoughts. If a man speaks or acts with a pure thought, happiness follows him, like a shadow that never leaves him.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Conversely, our existence is built upon and formed by our thoughts. Pure thoughts result in happiness. Happiness accompanies the individual like an ever-present shadow. This emphasizes the positive and enduring outcome of mental purity.

buddhist.text: "He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me,"--in those who harbour such thoughts hatred will never cease.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: When individuals dwell on grievances and injustices. Harboring such negative thoughts perpetuates animosity. Hatred will perpetually remain within them. This shows how nursing resentments sustains conflict.

buddhist.text: "He abused me, he beat me, he defeated me, he robbed me,"--in those who do not harbour such thoughts hatred will cease.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: If one chooses not to dwell on past wrongs. By releasing thoughts of ill-treatment. Hatred will come to an end for them. This suggests that letting go of resentment leads to peace.

buddhist.text: For hatred does not cease by hatred at any time: hatred ceases by love, this is an old rule.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: It is a fundamental principle that hatred cannot be overcome by more hatred. Instead, love is the sole means by which hatred ceases. This wisdom is presented as an enduring "old rule". Underlining its timeless and universal truth.

buddhist.text: The world does not know that we must all come to an end here;--but those who know it, their quarrels cease at once.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Most people are oblivious to the impermanence of life. However, those who comprehend that all existence here must end. For them, disputes and conflicts immediately cease. This understanding of mortality leads to the cessation of quarrels.

buddhist.text: He who lives looking for pleasures only, his senses uncontrolled, immoderate in his food, idle, and weak, Mara (the tempter) will certainly overthrow him, as the wind throws down a weak tree.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One who constantly seeks only pleasures, with uncontrolled senses. Being unrestrained in eating, lazy, and feeble, is vulnerable. Mara, the tempter, will easily defeat them. Like a weak tree toppled by the wind, they will be overthrown.

buddhist.text: He who lives without looking for pleasures, his senses well controlled, moderate in his food, faithful and strong, him Mara will certainly not overthrow, any more than the wind throws down a rocky mountain.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Conversely, one who lives without seeking excessive pleasures. With well-controlled senses, moderate food, and inner strength. Mara will be unable to overcome such a person. They are like a rocky mountain, unmovable by wind, symbolizing steadfastness.

buddhist.text: He who wishes to put on the yellow dress without having cleansed himself from sin, who disregards temperance and truth, is unworthy of the yellow dress.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A person desiring to wear the monk's yellow robe. Yet, they have not purified themselves from sin. If they neglect temperance and truth, they are unworthy. This signifies that outward symbols are meaningless without inner virtue.

buddhist.text: But he who has cleansed himself from sin, is well grounded in all virtues, and regards also temperance and truth, he is indeed worthy of the yellow dress.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The truly deserving wearer of the yellow dress is one purified from sin. They are firmly established in all virtues. And genuinely upholds temperance and truth. This shows that inner transformation makes one truly worthy.

buddhist.text: They who imagine truth in untruth, and see untruth in truth, never arrive at truth, but follow vain desires.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Individuals who perceive falsehood as truth and truth as untruth. Their understanding is fundamentally flawed. They will, therefore, never reach true understanding. Instead, they pursue empty and futile desires.

buddhist.text: They who know truth in truth, and untruth in untruth, arrive at truth, and follow true desires.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Conversely, those who accurately discern truth from untruth. Possess a clear and precise perception. Such individuals will indeed attain truth. And their aspirations will align with what is genuine and beneficial.

buddhist.text: As rain breaks through an ill-thatched house, passion will break through an unreflecting mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Just as rain easily penetrates a poorly constructed roof. Similarly, passion will readily permeate. An unreflecting mind, lacking mental defenses. This metaphor illustrates the mind's vulnerability to overwhelming emotions.

buddhist.text: As rain does not break through a well-thatched house, passion will not break through a well-reflecting mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: In contrast, a strongly and well-thatched house resists rain. Likewise, passion cannot penetrate. A well-reflecting mind, which is mindful and disciplined. This highlights the protection offered by inner control against desires.

buddhist.text: The evil-doer mourns in this world, and he mourns in the next; he mourns in both. He mourns and suffers when he sees the evil of his own work.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: An individual who performs evil deeds experiences sorrow in this life. They also suffer in their next existence, enduring grief in both realms. This mourning and suffering arise from witnessing the consequences. Of their own harmful actions.

buddhist.text: The virtuous man delights in this world, and he delights in the next; he delights in both. He delights and rejoices, when he sees the purity of his own work.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: In contrast, a virtuous person finds joy in both this world. And the next, experiencing delight in both. Their happiness stems from observing the purity. And goodness of their own deeds.

buddhist.text: The evil-doer suffers in this world, and he suffers in the next; he suffers in both. He suffers when he thinks of the evil he has done; he suffers more when going on the evil path.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The evil-doer endures suffering in both present and future lives. Their distress arises from reflecting on past wrongdoings. Suffering intensifies as they persist in the evil path. This emphasizes the compounding nature of negative actions.

buddhist.text: The virtuous man is happy in this world, and he is happy in the next; he is happy in both. He is happy when he thinks of the good he has done; he is still more happy when going on the good path.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A virtuous person finds happiness in this life and the next. Their joy comes from contemplating their good deeds. This happiness further increases as they continue on the good path. Illustrating the reinforcing positive cycle of virtuous conduct.

buddhist.text: The thoughtless man, even if he can recite a large portion (of the law), but is not a doer of it, has no share in the priesthood, but is like a cowherd counting the cows of others.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A thoughtless person, despite knowing much scripture. If they fail to practice what they learn, they gain no true spiritual share. They are likened to a cowherd merely tallying others' cattle. Indicating knowledge without action is spiritually barren.

buddhist.text: The follower of the law, even if he can recite only a small portion (of the law), but, having forsaken passion and hatred and foolishness, possesses true knowledge and serenity of mind, he, caring for nothing in this world or that to come, has indeed a share in the priesthood.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A true follower, even with limited scriptural knowledge. Has abandoned passion, hatred, and foolishness. Possessing true knowledge and mental serenity, free from worldly concerns. Such a person genuinely participates in the priesthood.

buddhist.text: Earnestness is the path of immortality (Nirvana), thoughtlessness the path of death. Those who are in earnest do not die, those who are thoughtless are as if dead already.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Earnestness is the direct path to immortality, or Nirvana. Conversely, thoughtlessness leads to spiritual death. Those who are earnest truly live and do not die. While the thoughtless are metaphorically already dead.

buddhist.text: Those who are advanced in earnestness, having understood this clearly, delight in earnestness, and rejoice in the knowledge of the Ariyas (the elect).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Individuals who have progressed significantly in earnestness. Having clearly grasped its importance, find joy in it. They also delight in the wisdom of the Ariyas, the elect. Describing the profound satisfaction from spiritual dedication.

buddhist.text: These wise people, meditative, steady, always possessed of strong powers, attain to Nirvana, the highest happiness.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Wise individuals are meditative, unwavering, and possess strong inner powers. Through these qualities, they are able to achieve Nirvana. Nirvana is unequivocally described as the highest form of happiness. This outlines the qualities leading to ultimate liberation.

buddhist.text: If an earnest person has roused himself, if he is not forgetful, if his deeds are pure, if he acts with consideration, if he restrains himself, and lives according to law,--then his glory will increase.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: An earnest person who is awakened and remains mindful. Whose actions are pure, considerate, and self-controlled. And who lives in harmony with the law. Such a person will inevitably see their glory and reputation grow.

buddhist.text: By rousing himself, by earnestness, by restraint and control, the wise man may make for himself an island which no flood can overwhelm.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Through self-arousal, earnestness, and diligent self-control. A wise person can construct an unassailable inner refuge. This spiritual "island" remains secure against any overwhelming "flood". Symbolizing unshakeable mental stability amidst life's challenges.

buddhist.text: Fools follow after vanity, men of evil wisdom. The wise man keeps earnestness as his best jewel.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Fools pursue empty vanity and possess misguided understanding. In sharp contrast, the wise individual treasures earnestness. They consider earnestness to be their most valuable possession. This highlights the fundamental difference in values between the foolish and the wise.

buddhist.text: Follow not after vanity, nor after the enjoyment of love and lust! He who is earnest and meditative, obtains ample joy.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One should avoid chasing vanity or indulging in sensual desires. Instead, those who are earnest and devoted to meditation. Will attain abundant joy and profound contentment. This encourages spiritual focus over fleeting physical pleasures.

buddhist.text: When the learned man drives away vanity by earnestness, he, the wise, climbing the terraced heights of wisdom, looks down upon the fools, serene he looks upon the toiling crowd, as one that stands on a mountain looks down upon them that stand upon the plain.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A learned person, through earnestness, sheds vanity. This wise individual ascends to the pinnacle of wisdom. From this lofty vantage, they serenely observe the struggling masses. Like a mountain-dweller viewing those on the plain, signifying superior insight.

buddhist.text: Earnest among the thoughtless, awake among the sleepers, the wise man advances like a racer, leaving behind the hack.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The wise person is earnest amidst the heedless. They remain awakened while others are asleep in ignorance. Such an individual progresses rapidly, like a swift racer. Leaving behind the slow or uninspired, emphasizing their advancement.

buddhist.text: By earnestness did Maghavan (Indra) rise to the lordship of the gods. People praise earnestness; thoughtlessness is always blamed.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Maghavan (Indra) achieved his divine leadership through earnestness. Earnestness is consistently praised by people. While thoughtlessness always incurs blame. This illustrates earnestness as a highly lauded quality leading to elevated status.

buddhist.text: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in earnestness, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, moves about like fire, burning all his fetters, small or large.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A mendicant who finds joy in earnestness and fears thoughtlessness. They advance with the intensity of fire. Burning away all their attachments, both great and small. Leading to complete liberation from bonds.

buddhist.text: A Bhikshu (mendicant) who delights in reflection, who looks with fear on thoughtlessness, cannot fall away (from his perfect state)--he is close upon Nirvana.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A mendicant who enjoys reflection and is wary of thoughtlessness. Such a person remains steadfast in their perfected state. They are incredibly near to attaining Nirvana. Highlighting the path to liberation through mindful contemplation.

buddhist.text: As a fletcher makes straight his arrow, a wise man makes straight his trembling and unsteady thought, which is difficult to guard, difficult to hold back.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Just as an arrow-maker straightens a crooked arrow. A wise person similarly disciplines their mind. Our thoughts are naturally trembling, unsteady, and hard to control. This emphasizes the constant effort required for mental mastery.

buddhist.text: As a fish taken from his watery home and thrown on dry ground, our thought trembles all over in order to escape the dominion of Mara (the tempter).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Our thoughts, in their yearning for freedom, are like a fish out of water. They struggle intensely, trembling to escape. This struggle is against the control of Mara, the tempter. Illustrating the mind's deep urge to break free from negative influences.

buddhist.text: It is good to tame the mind, which is difficult to hold in and flighty, rushing wherever it listeth; a tamed mind brings happiness.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: It is profoundly beneficial to tame the mind. The mind is inherently difficult to restrain, restless, and prone to wander. However, a disciplined and tamed mind brings true happiness. This underscores the great reward of mental self-control.

buddhist.text: Let the wise man guard his thoughts, for they are difficult to perceive, very artful, and they rush wherever they list: thoughts well guarded bring happiness.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A wise person should diligently protect their thoughts. Thoughts are subtle, cunning, and tend to roam freely. Nonetheless, well-guarded thoughts lead to happiness. Reinforcing the importance of constant vigilance over one's mind.

buddhist.text: Those who bridle their mind which travels far, moves about alone, is without a body, and hides in the chamber (of the heart), will be free from the bonds of Mara (the tempter).
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Those who can control their far-ranging, solitary, bodiless mind. Even though it is hidden deep within the heart. By restraining this mind, they become free from Mara's bonds. Highlighting liberation achieved through deep mental mastery.

buddhist.text: If a man's thoughts are unsteady, if he does not know the true law, if his peace of mind is troubled, his knowledge will never be perfect.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: If a person's thoughts are unstable and they lack understanding of the true law. And if their inner peace is disturbed. Then their knowledge will never reach perfection. This indicates that mental stability is crucial for true wisdom.

buddhist.text: If a man's thoughts are not dissipated, if his mind is not perplexed, if he has ceased to think of good or evil, then there is no fear for him while he is watchful.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: When a person's thoughts are focused and their mind is clear. And they have transcended dualistic thinking of good or evil. As long as they remain vigilant, they will experience no fear. This describes a state of profound inner peace and fearlessness.

buddhist.text: Knowing that this body is (fragile) like a jar, and making this thought firm like a fortress, one should attack Mara (the tempter) with the weapon of knowledge, one should watch him when conquered, and should never rest.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Recognizing the body's fragility, like a jar, and holding this thought firmly. One should combat Mara using knowledge as a weapon. Even after defeating the tempter, one must remain vigilant. And should never cease in their spiritual efforts.

buddhist.text: Before long, alas! this body will lie on the earth, despised, without understanding, like a useless log.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The sources reflect on the inevitable impermanence of the body. Soon, this physical form will become lifeless. It will lie discarded on the earth, despised and devoid of consciousness. Like nothing more than a useless, fallen log.

buddhist.text: Whatever a hater may do to a hater, or an enemy to an enemy, a wrongly-directed mind will do us greater mischief.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The harm inflicted by enemies upon each other. Is far less damaging than the mischief caused by one's own misguided mind. This highlights that internal negativity is more destructive. Warning against the self-inflicted harm of uncontrolled thoughts.

buddhist.text: Not a mother, not a father will do so much, nor any other relative; a well-directed mind will do us greater service.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The beneficial actions of a mother, father, or any relative. However great, are surpassed in their service. By the profound and positive impact of a well-directed mind. This emphasizes the unparalleled value of mental discipline and virtue.

buddhist.text: Who shall overcome this earth, and the world of Yama (the lord of the departed), and the world of the gods? Who shall find out the plainly shown path of virtue, as a clever man finds out the (right) flower?
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The verse poses questions regarding who can conquer this world. And also the realms of Yama (death) and the gods. It asks who can discover the clear path of virtue. Comparing it to a clever person finding the correct flower.

buddhist.text: The disciple will overcome the earth, and the world of Yama, and the world of the gods. The disciple will find out the plainly shown path of virtue, as a clever man finds out the (right) flower.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: The disciple is the one who will conquer the earth. They will also overcome the worlds of Yama and the gods. It is the disciple who will discover the plainly shown path of virtue. Much like a clever person discerning the correct flower.

buddhist.text: He who knows that this body is like froth, and has learnt that it is as unsubstantial as a mirage, will break the flower-pointed arrow of Mara, and never see the king of death.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: One who understands the body's nature as froth or a mirage. Such a person will shatter Mara's deceptive arrows. They will escape the dominion of the "king of death". This emphasizes liberation through realizing the impermanence and unreality of phenomena.

buddhist.text: Death carries off a man who is gathering flowers and whose mind is distracted, as a flood carries off a sleeping village.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Death claims individuals who are preoccupied with fleeting pleasures ("gathering flowers"). And whose minds are distracted from truth. Like a sudden, overwhelming flood sweeping away a slumbering village. This warns against heedlessness and attachment to ephemeral enjoyments.

buddhist.text: Death subdues a man who is gathering flowers, and whose mind is distracted, before he is satiated in his pleasures.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: Death overtakes individuals who are still absorbed in seeking pleasures. And whose minds are uncollected. This occurs before they have fully satisfied their desires. It reiterates the unexpected and often premature arrival of death for the pleasure-seeking.

buddhist.text: As the bee collects nectar and departs without injuring the flower, or its colour or scent, so let a sage dwell in his village.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A bee gathers nectar from a flower without causing any harm. It leaves the flower's color and scent undisturbed. Similarly, a sage should reside within their community. Interacting with the world without causing damage or selfishly exploiting it.

buddhist.text: Not the perversities of others, not their sins of commission or omission, but his own misdeeds and negligences should a sage take notice of.
buddhist.author: Buddha
buddhist.explanation: A true sage should not concern themselves with the faults of others. Instead, their focus must be directed inwards. A sage should diligently observe and rectify their own misdeeds. Emphasizing self-reflection and personal accountability over external criticism.

buddhist.text: The greatest gift is the gift of peace.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Chaos is inherent in all compounded things. Strive on with diligence.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Better than a thousand hollow words, is one word that brings peace.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The end of suffering is the awakening to the truth.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Just as a candle cannot burn without fire, men cannot exist without a spiritual life.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: However many holy words you read, however many you speak, what good will they do you if you do not act on them?
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: To be idle is a short road to death and to be diligent is a long road to life.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Conquer the angry one by love. Conquer the evil one by good. Conquer the stingy one by giving. Conquer the liar by truth.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: You yourself, as much as anybody in the entire universe, deserve your love and affection.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Avoid evil, do good, purify the mind. This is the teaching of the Buddhas.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The foot feels the foot when it feels the ground.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: If we could see the miracle of a single flower clearly, our whole life would change.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The only way to happiness is to cease worrying about things which are beyond the power of our will.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Holding on to anger is like grasping a hot coal with the intent of throwing it at someone else; you are the one who gets burned.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Reshape yourself through the power of your will; otherwise, your will be an enemy.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: To be kind to all, to love all, to serve all, to be happy, to be contented, to be peaceful.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Let us rise up and be thankful, for if we didn’t learn a lot today, at least we learned a little, and if we didn’t learn a little, at least we didn’t get sick, and if we got sick, at least we didn’t die; so, let us all be thankful.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Better than living a hundred years without seeing the highest truth, is one day of life seeing the highest truth.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Purity or impurity depends on oneself; no one can purify another.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The greatest prayer is patience.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Meditate. Live purely. Be quiet. Do your work with mastery. Like the moon, come out from behind the clouds! Shine.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Abandon attachment to any and all things.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: One day's practice is better than a thousand years of thinking.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: There is no path to happiness. Happiness is the path.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The wise man is one who knows what he does not know.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The tongue is a sharp knife that kills without drawing blood.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Empty your mind, be formless, shapeless – like water.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Have compassion for all beings, rich and poor alike; each has their suffering. Some suffer too much, others too little.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: If you want to know your past, look into your present condition. If you want to know your future, look into your present actions.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The greatest wealth is to live content with little.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Drop by drop is the water pot filled. Likewise, the wise man, gathering it little by little, fills himself with good.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: To abstain from all evil, to cultivate good, and to purify one's mind – this is the teaching of the Buddhas.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The whole secret of existence is to have no fear. Never fear what will become of you, depend on no one. Only the moment you reject all help are you freed.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: All experiences are preceded by mind, having mind as their master, created by mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: There is no fire like passion, no shark like hatred, no snare like folly, no torrent like greed.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: If you do not change direction, you may end up where you are heading.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Everything is impermanent.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Speak or act with an impure mind and trouble will follow you as the wheel follows the ox that draws the cart.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The greatest delusion is fear.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Looking at a tree is looking at meditation.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Know from experience that no pleasure is a good thing if it brings a later pain.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Your most precious possession is not your financial assets. Your most precious possession is your time. You may or may not get more money, but you will never get more time.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: To be attached to nothing, to want nothing, to love nothing.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: What is essential is to practice, not to know.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Those who are free of resentful thoughts surely find peace.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Happiness does not depend on what you have or who you are. It solely relies on how you think.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Like a lotus flower, we too have the ability to rise from the mud, bloom out of the darkness and radiate into the world.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: If you want to keep your memories, you have to keep your mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: He who loves 50 people has 50 woes; he who loves no one has no woes.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The gift of truth excels all other gifts.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The mind is hard to check, swift, it flies wherever it wishes. To tame it is good. A tamed mind brings happiness.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Whatever words we utter should be chosen with care for people will hear them and be influenced by them for good or ill.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The greatest blessing is contentment.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: As a bee gathers nectar without harming the flower, so should a sage move through life.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Your own self is your master; who else could be? With self-control, you gain a master hard to find.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Let go of the past, let go of the future, let go of the present, and cross over to the other shore.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Believe nothing, no matter where you read it, or who said it, no matter if I have said it, unless it agrees with your own reason and your own common sense.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: He who acts under the impulse of his desires is carried along by the stream.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Like a deep lake, clear and still, so a wise person becomes peaceful upon hearing the teachings.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The way is not in the sky. The way is in the heart.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Speak only words that are kind, peaceful, and truthful.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Better than a thousand hollow words is one word that brings peace.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Do not pursue the past. Do not lose yourself in the future. The past no longer is. The future has not yet come. Looking deeply at life as it is in the very here and now, the practitioner dwells in stability and freedom.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: If you want to understand your past, look at your present conditions. If you want to understand your future, look at your present actions.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The greatest prayer is patience.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Radiate boundless love towards the entire world—above, below, and across—unhindered, without ill will, without enmity.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Every morning we are born again. What we do today is what matters most.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: He who experiences the unity of life sees his own Self in all beings, and all beings in his own Self, and looks on everything with an impartial eye.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The truth is not a theory, but a liberation.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: To understand everything is to forgive everything.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Just as a candle cannot burn without fire, men cannot exist without a spiritual life.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The only real failure in life is not to be true to the best one knows.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Know from experience that no pleasure is a good thing if it brings a later pain.

buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The wise ones who are intent on meditation, who delight in the peace of renunciation, such mindful ones, even the gods admire.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The mind is everything. What you think you become.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: If you light a lamp for someone else, it will also brighten your own path.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: An ungrateful mind is a monster, which devours that by which it is nourished.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: All experiences are preceded by mind, having mind as their master, created by mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Just as a tree, though cut down, sprouts up again if its roots are undamaged and strong, so also, if the roots of craving are not destroyed, the suffering sprouts forth again and again.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: To enjoy good health, to bring true happiness to one's family, to bring peace to all, one must first discipline and control one's own mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Three things cannot be long hidden: the sun, the moon, and the truth.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The greatest victory is that over oneself.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: We are shaped by our thoughts; we become what we think. When the mind is pure, joy follows like a shadow that never leaves.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The mind is hard to check, swift, it flies wherever it wishes. To tame it is good. A tamed mind brings happiness.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Whatever words we utter should be chosen with care for people will hear them and be influenced by them for good or ill.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The greatest blessing is contentment.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: As a bee gathers nectar without harming the flower, so should a sage move through life.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Your own self is your master; who else could be? With self-control, you gain a master hard to find.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Let go of the past, let go of the future, let go of the present, and cross over to the other shore.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Believe nothing, no matter where you read it, or who said it, no matter if I have said it, unless it agrees with your own reason and your own common sense.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: He who acts under the impulse of his desires is carried along by the stream.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Like a deep lake, clear and still, so a wise person becomes peaceful upon hearing the teachings.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The way is not in the sky. The way is in the heart.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Speak only words that are kind, peaceful, and truthful.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Better than a thousand hollow words is one word that brings peace.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Do not pursue the past. Do not lose yourself in the future. The past no longer is. The future has not yet come. Looking deeply at life as it is in the very here and now, the practitioner dwells in stability and freedom.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: If you want to understand your past, look at your present conditions. If you want to understand your future, look at your present actions.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The greatest prayer is patience.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Radiate boundless love towards the entire world—above, below, and across—unhindered, without ill will, without enmity.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Every morning we are born again. What we do today is what matters most.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: He who experiences the unity of life sees his own Self in all beings, and all beings in his own Self, and looks on everything with an impartial eye.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The truth is not a theory, but a liberation.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: To understand everything is to forgive everything.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Just as a candle cannot burn without fire, men cannot exist without a spiritual life.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The only real failure in life is not to be true to the best one knows.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Know from experience that no pleasure is a good thing if it brings a later pain.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: All living beings are subject to decay. Achieve your own salvation with diligence.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The path is not to be found in the sky. The path is in the heart.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Holding onto anger is like drinking poison and expecting the other person to die.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Peace comes from within. Do not seek it without.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: To be kind to all, to love all, to serve all, to be happy, to be contented, to be peaceful.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Do not dwell in the past, do not dream of the future, concentrate the mind on the present moment.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: It is better to conquer yourself than to win a thousand battles. Then the victory is yours. It cannot be taken from you, not by angels or by demons, heaven or hell.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Better than worshipping gods is obedience to the laws of righteousness.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: An insincere and evil friend is more to be feared than a wild beast; a wild beast may wound your body, but an evil friend will wound your mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Just as the river flows into the sea, so all good actions lead to Nirvana.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Do not be led by others, make your own decision.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Those who cling to perceptions and views wander long in the world.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: One moment can change a day, one day can change a life, one life can change the world.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The whole secret of existence is to have no fear.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The greatest evil is a lack of love and compassion.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The wise ones who are intent on meditation, who delight in the peace of renunciation, such mindful ones, even the gods admire.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Better than living a hundred years, not seeing the highest truth, is one day of life seeing the highest truth.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Empty your mind, be formless, shapeless – like water.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Live purely. Be quiet. Do your work with mastery. Like the moon, come out from behind the clouds! Shine.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: There are only two mistakes one can make along the road to truth; not going all the way, and not starting.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The gift of truth excels all other gifts.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: An idea that is developed and put into action is more important than an idea that exists only as an idea.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The root of suffering is attachment.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Even death is not to be feared by one who has lived wisely.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: What you think, you become. What you feel, you attract. What you imagine, you create.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Those who have failed to work toward the truth have missed the purpose of living.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Your most precious possession is not your financial assets. Your most precious possession is your time.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: A dog is not considered a good dog because he is a good barker. A man is not considered a good man because he is a good talker.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Purity or impurity depends on oneself; no one can purify another.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The trouble is, you think you have time.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: If you truly loved yourself, you would never harm another.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: There is no fire like passion, no shark like hatred, no snare like folly, no torrent like greed.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: If you do not change direction, you may end up where you are heading.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Everything is impermanent.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Speak or act with an impure mind and trouble will follow you as the wheel follows the ox that draws the cart.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Looking at a tree is looking at meditation.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Know from experience that no pleasure is a good thing if it brings a later pain.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: To be attached to nothing, to want nothing, to love nothing.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: What is essential is to practice, not to know.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Those who are free of resentful thoughts surely find peace.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Happiness does not depend on what you have or who you are. It solely relies on how you think.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Like a lotus flower, we too have the ability to rise from the mud, bloom out of the darkness and radiate into the world.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: If you want to keep your memories, you have to keep your mind.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The greatest gift is the gift of peace.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The end of suffering is the awakening to the truth.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: One day's practice is better than a thousand years of thinking.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: There is no path to happiness. Happiness is the path.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The wise man is one who knows what he does not know.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: The tongue is a sharp knife that kills without drawing blood.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: Have compassion for all beings, rich and poor alike; each has their suffering. Some suffer too much, others too little.
buddhist.author: Buddha

buddhist.text: If you want to know your past, look into your present condition. If you want to know your future, look into your present actions.
buddhist.author: Buddha

motivational.author: Steve Jobs

motivational.text: Believe you can and you're halfway there.

motivational.text: Success is not final, failure is not fatal: it is the courage to continue that counts.

motivational.text: The best way to predict the future is to create it.

motivational.text: Don't watch the clock; do what it does. Keep going.

motivational.text: The only limit to our realization of tomorrow will be our doubts of today.

motivational.text: The only place where success comes before work is in the dictionary.

motivational.text: Hardships often prepare ordinary people for an extraordinary destiny.

motivational.text: You are never too old to set another goal or to dream a new dream.

motivational.text: The mind is everything. What you think you become.

motivational.text: Start where you are. Use what you have. Do what you can.

motivational.text: The secret of getting ahead is getting started.

motivational.text: Go confidently in the direction of your dreams! Live the life you have imagined.

motivational.text: Your time is limited, so don't waste it living someone else's life.

motivational.text: The best revenge is massive success.

motivational.text: Quality is not an act, it is a habit.

motivational.text: Strength does not come from physical capacity. It comes from an indomitable will.

motivational.text: It always seems impossible until it's done.

motivational.text: The greatest glory in living lies not in never falling, but in rising every time we fall.

motivational.text: Develop success from failures. Discouragement and failure are two of the surest stepping stones to success.
